snippet: A partial statue unearthed in southeastern Turkey depicts Suppiluliuma, who ruled in the ninth century B.C.
abstract: Team of archaeologists from the University of Toronto discover a giant statue of a Turkish king that dates back 3,000 years; piece, found in southeastern Turkey, demonstrates that creativity and intellect flourished in the Iron Age despite the absence of big empires.
lead_paragraph: A partial statue unearthed in southeastern Turkey depicts Suppiluliuma, who ruled in the ninth century B.C.

headline.print_headline: Iron Age Creativity In a Turkish King’s Image
headline.seo: 3,000-Year-Old King Statue Demonstrates Iron Age Creativity
headline.main: Iron Age Creativity in a King’s Image
